questions.text: Genetic polymorphisms in certain hepatic enzymes involved in drug metabolism are established to be responsible for variations in analgesic response to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Codeine, hydrocodone, and oxycodone are metabolized by the cytochrome P450 isoform CYP2D6, and variations in analgesic response to these drugs have been attributed to genotypic polymorphisms in this isozyme. In the case of codeine, this may be especially important since the drug is demethylated by CYP2D6 to form the active metabolite, morphine

questions.text: A patient on meperidine developed tachycardia, hypertension, hyperpyrexia, and seizures following intake of taking a drug for a psychiatric condition, Which drug is most likely to be responsible for this untoward interaction with meperidine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Concomitant administration of meperidine and monoamine oxidase inhibitors such as isocarboxazid or phenelzine has resulted in life-threatening hyperpyrexic reactions that may culminate in seizures or coma. Such reactions have occurred even when the MAO inhibitor was administered more than a week after a patient had been treated with meperidine. Note that concomitant use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and meperidine has resulted in the serotonin syndrome, another life-threatening drug interaction

questions.text: Mecasermin useful in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Mecasermin- is a Recombinant human  IGF analogue

Mecasermin is administered by subcutaneous injection 

Mecasermin is FDA-approved for patients with impaired growth secondary to mutations in the GHR or postreceptor signaling pathway, patients who develop antibodies against GH that interfere with its action, and patients with IGF-1 gene defects that lead to primary IGF-1 deficiency. 

Side effects of mecasermin include hypoglycemia and lipohypertrophy.

Contraindications. Mecasermin should not be used for growth promotion in patients with closed epiphyses. It should not be given to patients
with active or suspected neoplasia and should be stopped if evidence of neoplasia develops.

questions.text: Which one of the following is called as suicide(irreversible) aromatase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Aminoglutethimide inhibits aromatase activity, but its use is limited by its lack of selectivity and its side effects

Both steroidal (e.g., formestane and exemestane) and nonsteroidal (e.g., anastrozole, letrozole, and vorozole) 

Steroidal, or type I, agents are substrate analogues that act as
suicide inhibitors to irreversibly inactivate aromatase, whereas the nonsteroidal,or type II, agents inactivate reversibly

Exemestane, letrozole, and anastrozole are currently
approved in the U.S. for the treatment of breast cancer

questions.text: Which one of the following is the longest acting PDE 5 blocker
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PDE5 Inhibitors
Available inhibitors of PDE5 include sildenafil, vardenafil, tadalafil, and
avanafil. All of these agents compete for cyclic GMP binding at the site of
cyclic GMP hydrolysis on PDE5. PDE5 inhibitors are also used in treating
pulmonary arterial hypertension, erectile dysfunction

Maximum duration of action (hr) SILDENAFIL12, VARDENAFIL 10,  TADALAFIL36 , AVANAFIL6

Sildenafil, Tadalafil, Vardenafil- irst-line therapy for moderate PAH

• Avoid using  nitrates and α adrenergic antagonists along with PDE 5 blockers due to hypotension
• Major side effects: epistaxis, headache, dyspepsia, vision or hearing loss 
flushing, insomnia, dyspnea, priapism
• Vardenafil, currently not recommended due to limited evidence for efficacy in PAH

Sildenafil and vardenafil able to block PDE 6 on the retina, causing colour vision(blue) defect

choices.text: It cannot be mixed with short-acting insulin preparations
Has a lower risk of hypoglycaemia than NPH
Is a long-acting analogue of human insulin
It is prepared by modifying amino acid sequence only in A chain

questions.text: Regarding insulin glargine which is false statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Insulin glargine is a long-acting analogue of human insulin. Two arginine residues are added to the C terminus of the B chain, and an asparagine molecule in position 21 on the A chain is replaced with glycine. Insulin glargine is a clear solution with a pH of 4.0, which stabilizes the insulin hexamer.

Owing to insulin glargine’s acidic pH, it cannot be mixed with short-acting insulin preparations that are formulated at a neutral pH.

Glargine has a sustained peakless absorption profile and provides more predictable 24-h insulin coverage than NPH insulin when injected once
daily. Clinical trial data suggest that glargine has a lower risk of hypoglycemia, particularly overnight compared to NPH insulin

Nateglinide, repaglinide

questions.text: Which one of the following DPP4 inhibitor is safe in renal failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Alogliptin, saxagliptin, sitagliptin, and vildagliptin circulate primarily in unbound form and are excreted largely unchanged in the urine; lower doses should be given to patients with reduced renal function. 

Linagliptin binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system, with little renal clearance.

questions.text:
Regarding PPIs find out the true and false statements
A.    PPIs are called as hit and run drugs
B.    PPIs are activated in alkaline medium
C.    Lansoprazole safe in pregnancy
D.    PPIs are metabolised by CYP2C19 enzyme
E.    Vonoprazan is the irreversible PPI
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PPIs are called as hit and run drugs, because they have short plasma half life but acting for longer time due to irreversible inhibition of proton pump
PPIs are activated in acidic medium
Lansoprazole safe in pregnancy
PPIs are metabolised by CYP2C19 enzyme
Vonoprazan is the irreversible PPI

Aprepitant , fosaprepitant, Rolapitant, Netupitant – neurokinin 1 antagonist

Aprepitant and ondansetron are both used to reduce or prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Ondansetron is an antagonist at 5-HT3 receptors

questions.text: Patient who is treated with alosetron must diligently monitor for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alosetron is a 5-H 3 receptor antagonist that reduces GI contractility with decreased colonic transit and increased fluid absorption. The
drug was withdrawn from the US market (then reapproved by the FDA) because ofan unusually high incidence of ischemic colitis (up to 3 per 1000 patients).

questions.text: Which one of the following drug is the CFTR activator useful in the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Linaclotide is approved for the treatment of chronic constipation and IBS with predominant constipation. Linaclotide activates guanylyl cyclase-C on the luminal intestinal epithelial surface, which leads to activation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) leading to increased chloride-rich secretion and acceleration of intestinal transit

questions.text: Which is proton pump inhibitor having longest half life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


tenatoprazole is a PPI containing an imidazopyridine ring instead of a benzimidazole ring, which promotes irreversible proton pump inhibition. This agent has a longer half-life than the other PPIs and may be beneficial for inhibiting nocturnal acid secretion, which has significant relevance in GERD.
Inhibitors of potassium competitive binding of the H+,K+-ATPase are  Revaprazan and venoprazan

questions.text: First-line treatment for Menetrier’s disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Medical therapy with anticholinergic agents, prostaglandins, PPIs, prednisone, somatostatin analogues (octreotide) and H2 receptor antagonists yields varying results

The discovery that MD is associated with overstimulation of the EGFR pathway has led to the successful use of the EGF inhibitory antibody, cetuximab, in these patients
Cetuximab is now considered the first-line treatment for MD, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial protein loss despite therapy with this agent.

questions.text: Guanylate cyclase-C activator useful in treating of constipation is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lubiprostone- is a bicyclic fatty acid that stimulates chloride channels in the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells. Chloride secretion induces passive movement of sodium and water into the bowel lumen and improves bowel function.

Linaclotide is a minimally absorbed 14-amino-acid peptide guanylate cyclase-C (GC-C) agonist that
binds to and activates GC-C on the luminal surface of intestinal epithelium. Activation of GC-C results in generation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which triggers secretion of fluid,
sodium, and bicarbonate.

May cause hypotension due to its alpha blocking action

questions.text: By seeing the lipid profile report find out Which of the following drugs is most likely to be the one that this patient received?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient presents with striking hypertriglyceridemia, elevated total cholesterol, and depressed HDL cholesterol. Six months after drug treatment was initiated, triglyceride and total cholesterol have dropped dramatically and HDL cholesterol level has doubled. The drug that is most likely to have achieved all of these desirable changes, particularly the large increase in HDL cholesterol, is niacin. Although gemfibrozil lowers triglyceride , it does not cause such large increases in HDL cholesterol and decreases in LDL cholesterol.

modafinil approved for treating narcolepsy, modafinil has had several positive clinical trials for use in cocaine withdrawal

Pemoline is structurally dissimilar to methylphenidate but elicits similar
changes in CNS function with minimal effects on the cardiovascular system. It is employed in treating ADHD. It can be given once daily because of its long t1/2. Clinical improvement may require treatment for 3–4 weeks. Use of pemoline has been associated with severe hepatic failure. The drug was discontinued

questions.text: Which NSAID undergoes enterohepatic circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Piroxicam It is a long-acting potent NSAID
with antiinflammatory potency similar to indomethacin
and good analgesic-antipyretic action.
It is a nonselective, reversible inhibitor of COX;
lowers PG concentration in synovial fluid and
inhibits platelet aggregation—prolonging bleeding
time. In addition, it decreases the production of
IgM rheumatoid factor and leucocyte chemotaxis.
Thus, it can inhibit inflammation in diverse
ways.
enterohepatic cycling occurs. Plasma t½ is long—
nearly 2 days.

questions.text: From the given diagram (bacterial protein synthesis), find out the antimicrobial drug acting on the letter mentioned in 3
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


(1) Aminoglycosides bind to several sites at 30S and 50S subunits as well as to their interface-freeze initiation,
interfere with polysome formation and cause misreading of mRNA code.

(2) Tetracyclines bind to 30S ribosome and inhibit aminoacyl tRNA attachment to the 'A' site.

(3) Chlorampheniool binds to 50S subunit-interferes with peptide bond formation and transfer of peptide chain from 'P' site.

(4) Ery1hromycin and clindamycin also bind to 50S ribosome and hinder translocation of the elongated peptide chain back from 'A' site to 'P' site and the ribosome does not move along the mRNA to expose the next codon. Peptide synthesis may be prematurely terminated.

choices.text: It is unsafe in decompensated cirrhosis

questions.text: Regarding sofosbuvir all are true except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sofosbuvir
Sofosbuvir is a prodrug based on a uridine analogue.
A high-fat meal increases sofosbuvir’s absorption
No dose adjustment is needed for this population; available data suggest sofosbuvir is safe and effective in individuals with decompensated cirrhosis
sofosbuvir should not be used in patients with eGFR of less than 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 or those with ESRD

Sofosbuvir is not a CYP substrate,, However, sofosbuvir is a
substrate for the efflux transporters Pgp and BCRP and should not be
used with potent inducers of these transporters (e.g., rifampin, St. John’s wort, phenytoin, carbamazepine).

cardiac monitoring in an inpatient setting is advised for the first 48 h of sofosbuvir-based treatment, with daily heart rate monitoring for an additional 2 weeks.

choices.text: Diarrhoea is the dose limiting toxicity

questions.text: Which is false regarding irinotecan is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 
The dose-limiting toxicity with all dosing schedules is delayed diarrhoea (35%), with or without neutropenia. 
A cholinergic syndrome resulting from the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase activity by irinotecan may occur within the first 24 h after irinotecan administration. Symptoms include acute diarrhea, diaphoresis, hypersalivation, abdominal cramps, visual accommodation disturbances, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and, less often, asymptomatic bradycardia. These effects are short
lasting and respond within minutes to atropine, 
Biliary excretion appears to be the primary elimination route of irinotecan, SN-38, and metabolites, although urinary excretion also contributes (14%–37%).

irreversible inhibitor of T790M-mutant EGFR,

Osimertinib is approved for metastatic NSCLC that has progressed after prior EGFR TKI treatment and is positive for the EGFR T790M mutation 
The most common adverse effects after osimertinib treatment are diarrhea and skin rash

choices.text: It is targeting against IL2 receptor
Used for the prophylaxis of renal transplantation
The t1/2 of basiliximab is 7 days

questions.text: Regarding basiliximab all are true except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 


Anti-IL-2 Receptor (Anti-CD25) Antibodies
Daclizumab is a humanized murine complementarity-determining
region/human IgG1 chimeric mAb. 
Basiliximab is a murine-human chimeric mAb. Both are licensed for use in conjunction with cyclosporine and corticosteroids for the prophylaxis of acute organ rejection in patients receiving renal transplants.
The t1/2 of basiliximab is 7 days.
Toxicity. Basiliximab and daclizumab seem to be relatively safe as induction agents, with most of the clinical trials reporting adverse reactions rates comparable to placebo. No cytokine-release syndrome has been noted, but anaphylactic reactions and rare lymphoproliferative disorders and opportunistic infections may occur. No drug interactions have been described.

questions.text: Which one of the following MAB approved for treaing SLE
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Belimumab, a mAb that targets BLYS, was recently approved for use inpatients with systemic lupus erythromatosus

questions.text: Which is the safer drug for maintenance therapy in case of Wilson disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Wilson disease Drug of choice

questions.text: All of the following drug matched properly with their antidote except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


For barbiturate poisoning, there is no specific antidote

Flumazenil is the antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning

questions.text: Which one of the following is the PDE I inhibitor
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to increase serum concentrations of conventional doses of methotrexate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Like other weak acids, methotrexate depends on active tubular excretion in the proximal tubule for efficient elimination. Probenecid competes with methotrexate for binding to the proximal tubule transporter and thereby decreases the rate of clearance of methotrexate

questions.text: Which  one of the following drug dose no need to modify in kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Among the quinolones pefloxacin, trovafloxacin, moxifloxacin undergoes biliary route of excretion, so no need of dosage adjustment in kidney disease
Trovafloxacin was withdrawn due to severe hepatotoxicity

questions.text: Laropiprant useful for treating
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Laropiprant (INN) was a drug used in combination with niacin to reduce blood cholesterol (LDL and VLDL) that is no longer sold, due to increases in side-effects with no cardiovascular benefit. Laropiprant itself has no cholesterol lowering effect, but it reduces facial flushes induced by niacin.

questions.text: Which of the following drug contra indicated in a patient with history of epilepsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


ATT causing seizure- INH, CYCLOSERINE
PYRAZINAMIDE- hepatotoxic, hyperuricemia
Delamanid- QT prolongation
ETHIONAMIDE- hypothyroidism

questions.text: Which of the following can increase metabolism of uric acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Allopurinol, febuxostat inhibits xanthine oxidase thereby inhibiting synthesis of uric acid
Rasburicase and pegloticase increases metabolism of uric acid
Probenicd promotes urinary excretion of uric acid

questions.text: Veno occlusive disease of liver (VOD) treated by which of the following agent
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Palbociclib, Amebaciclib, ribociclib- CDK 4/6(cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor-  Breast cancer
Olaparib, Rucaparib- inhibits Poly (ADP-Ribose) Polymerase(PARP) INHIBITOR useful for ovarian cancer
Belimumab—useful in SLE
Defirotide- anthi thrombotic agent useful to control alkylating agents induced hepatic vein thrombosis

questions.text: Which of the following has been shown to prolong life in patients with chronic congestive failure in spite of having a negative inotropic effect on cardiac contractility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Several beta blockers, including carvedilol, have been shown to prolong life in heart failure patients even though these drugs have a negative inotropic action on the heart. Their benefits presumably result from some other effect, and at least one β blocker has failed to show a mortality benefit

questions.text: Voxelotor useful in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

voxelotor is the first hemoglobin oxygen-affinity modulator.[6] Voxelotor has been shown to have disease-modifying potential by increasing hemoglobin levels and decreasing hemolysis indicators in sickle cell patients
